Introduction

Meckel diverticulum is a congenital anomaly that results from incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct during embryonic development, creating a diverticulum in the small intestine.  It is the most common congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract and follows the "rule of 2s."

Pathophysiology and risk factors



By 4 weeks gestation, the omphalomesenteric (vitelline) duct connects the yolk sac to the midgut, allowing nutrients to pass from the yolk sac to the developing embryo (

figure 1
).  Normally, the vitelline duct closes between 5 and 6 weeks gestation.  Incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct leads to a spectrum of anomalies (
figure 2
), including:



  • Meckel diverticulum (most common) results from partial closure of the vitelline duct, with the patent portion attached to the ileum.  A fibrous band may connect the tip of the diverticulum with the umbilicus.
  • Persistent vitelline duct results from complete failure of duct closure and results in a patent connection between the small intestine and the umbilicus, causing fecal discharge from the umbilicus.
  • Vitelline sinus results from partial closure of the vitelline duct, with the patent portion at the umbilicus; serous umbilical drainage may occur.
  • Vitelline duct cyst (enterocyst) results from obliteration of peripheral segments only, with a patent central segment remaining; patients are usually asymptomatic.


Meckel diverticulum is a true diverticulum (ie, contains all layers of the small intestine).  It is typically located within 2 feet (30.5 cm) of the ileocecal valve and varies in length, but is generally <2 inches (5.1 cm) (known as the "rule of 2s").



Approximately 50% of Meckel diverticula contain ectopic (heterotopic) tissue (ie, normal cells in an abnormal location), most commonly gastric, pancreatic, or colonic mucosa in origin.  The ectopic gastric parietal cells secrete hydrochloric acid, which can cause ulceration of distal ileal mucosa.  Ectopic pancreatic tissue is less common and can cause obstruction or inflammation.



Risk factors for Meckel diverticulum include male sex (male-to-female ratio is 2:1) and other congenital anomalies (eg, omphalocele, congenital heart disease).

Clinical presentation



The majority of Meckel diverticula do not cause symptoms and are discovered incidentally.  When symptomatic, patients generally have the following gastrointestinal symptoms:



  • Bleeding:  Secretion of hydrochloric acid by ectopic gastric parietal cells can cause distal mucosal ulceration with brisk, painless gastrointestinal bleeding but no associated systemic symptoms.  Although hematochezia is more common, patients may also have melena, depending on colonic transit time.  Ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding can cause iron deficiency anemia, which may present with fatigue and pallor in a patient with occult bleeding.
  • Obstruction:  Meckel diverticulum is the most common pathologic lead point for intussusception (
    figure 3
    ), a condition in which a proximal segment of bowel telescopes into a distal segment, causing severe, episodic abdominal pain.  Less commonly, Meckel diverticulum can present with intestinal obstruction due to volvulus, torsion, inversion, or herniation.  Intussusception and volvulus are more common in children.
  • Inflammation:  Meckel diverticulitis can occur due to occlusion of the diverticular opening (eg, fecalith, lymphoid hyperplasia, foreign body) and subsequent inflammation with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis.  Ongoing inflammation can lead to perforation and peritonitis.


Meckel diverticulum classically presents by age 2; however, patients can develop complications at any age.

Diagnosis



Diagnostic evaluation for Meckel diverticulum depends on the patient's presentation, as follows:

Bleeding



  • Meckel scan (
    image 1
    ) is a type of nuclear imaging in which technetium Tc 99m pertechnetate is administered and subsequently secreted by gastric parietal cells, allowing identification of ectopic gastric mucosa on scintigraphy.  Meckel scan is a noninvasive test that is highly sensitive and specific if there is ectopic gastric tissue; however, Meckel diverticula without ectopic gastric mucosa is not detectable, and patients require mesenteric arteriography or video capsule endoscopy.
  • Mesenteric arteriography shows an anomalous branch of the superior mesenteric artery that supplies the Meckel diverticulum.  Contrast extravasation may be visualized in patients with brisk bleeding.

Obstruction or inflammation



  • Ultrasonography and/or CT scan of the abdomen may be used to visualize Meckel diverticulum; however, these imaging modalities cannot readily differentiate Meckel diverticulum from other loops of bowel.


Laboratory findings are nonspecific.  Complete blood count may show anemia (if bleeding) and/or leukocytosis (if inflammation).  Of note, endoscopy and colonoscopy are normal in patients with Meckel diverticulum, and Meckel scan or video capsule endoscopy should be performed to locate small intestinal bleeding.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for Meckel diverticulum is broad and depends on the patient's presentation, as follows:

Bleeding



  • Inflammatory bowel disease:  Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis are chronic conditions that can cause gastrointestinal bleeding, often with abdominal pain and systemic symptoms (eg, weight loss, fatigue).
  • Infectious colitis:  Unlike Meckel diverticulum, infectious colitis presents with diarrhea, abdominal pain, and fever, in addition to bleeding.
  • Vascular malformations:  Although rare, vascular malformations (eg, intestinal lymphangiectasia) can cause painless gastrointestinal bleeding.

Obstruction



  • Intussusception:  Intussusception without Meckel diverticulum typically does not recur or cause persistent bleeding despite reduction.  Only 10% of cases of intussusception have an identifiable pathologic lead point (eg, Meckel diverticulum).
  • Volvulus:  Similar to intussusception, Meckel diverticulum can be a pathologic lead point in cases of volvulus.

Inflammation



  • Appendicitis:  presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis; however, the abdominal pain in Meckel diverticulitis is typically periumbilical, although the exact position of the pain can vary.
  • Colonic diverticulitis:  causes left lower quadrant abdominal pain.
  • Acute gastroenteritis:  typically presents with acute diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and fever.

Management



If Meckel diverticulum is detected incidentally on imaging in asymptomatic patients, no treatment is required.



However, surgical resection is required for symptomatic Meckel diverticulum.  The procedure is generally well-tolerated with few possible complications (eg, infection, bleeding).

Summary



Meckel diverticulum (
